NEW NATIONAL LIBRARY BUILDING


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chew Heng Ching -

    2. To ask the Minister for Community Development what is the progress regarding his Ministry's plan to build a modern National Library to replace the existing one at Stamford Road.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Tiong Bahru GRC): Question No. 2, Sir.

     The Minister of State for Community Development (Dr Seet Ai Mee) (for the Minister for Community Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    I am pleased to inform the House that the former Raffles Girls' School site at Queen Street has been earmarked for the new National Library Building.

    A library consultant for the project will be appointed in April this year. He will advise the Director, National Library, in the planning of the new National LIbrary Building, including provisions for state-of-the-art library technology.

GRASSROOTS GRANT FOR COMMUNITY PROJECTS
(Extension of projects)


    The following Question stood in the name of Mr Chew Heng Ching -

    3. To ask the Minister for Community Development if he will consider extending the grassroots grant set aside in every financial year for community projects to projects organised by the Civil Defence Coordinating Committees, Constituency Sports Clubs and other grassroots organisations.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Question No. 3, Sir.

     The Minister of State for Community Development (Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon) (for the Minister for Community Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    The grassroots grant set aside by the Government every financial year may be used for projects which Citizens' Consultative Committees (CCCs) and Residents' Committees (RCs) organise jointly with other grassroots organisations, including the Civil Defence Coordinating Committees and Constituency Sports Clubs.

    The Grassroots Grant Committee has in fact approved grants for a number of Civil Defence projects organised jointly by the grassroots organisations in a few constituencies.

    Grassroots organisations requiring grants for joint projects should submit their requests through the CCCs and their Advisers so that there will be better coordination in the application and allocation of the grassroots grants in each constituency.

    Apart from the grassroots grant, the Singapore Sports Council also gives an annual grant to each Constituency Sports Club. This annual grant varies according to the number of sports activities it organises.

    CCC Advisers should make full use of these annual grants to organise community projects and sports activities for the benefit of their constituents.

    Head L (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [15th March, 1990],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head L of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Dr Tan Cheng Bock].

    Question again proposed.

     The Minister for Education (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Bedok GRC, Dr Hong Hai, spoke yesterday on the teaching of Chinese as a second language and suggested that the Ministry should put greater emphasis on making the learning of CL2, as he said, a pleasure and a delight. I think that it may be appropriate for me to say a few words on this subject now and also on the topic of bilingualism in general. There are a number of points which I would like to make.

    The first point, Sir, is that we should not equate bilingualism with only the study of the mother tongue. Bilingualism means much more than the study of the mother tongue. Bilingualism means the study of English and the mother tongue. This, Sir, I emphasize, because it is a matter of which we should be quite clear as otherwise we are in danger of going off on the wrong track.

    Why does the Ministry of Education place so much importance on the study of English? After all, as Dr Hong Hai said yesterday, English is not our language. English is the language of another society, another culture. It was imported into Singapore when we were a British colony. But I submit, Sir, that there are two very cogent reasons why the study of English is important in a modern multi-racial, open economy society like Singapore.

    The first reason, Sir, is to build social cohesion in our multi-racial society. Precisely because English is not the mother tongue of any of the three main races in

Column: 336

Singapore and none of the three main races - Malay, Chinese and Indian - can claim any special affinity to the English language, this makes English neutral and an appropriate language for all races to use as a means of communicating with one another. With English as our common working language, working relations are facilitated. Efficiency is enhanced and there is greater understanding among Singaporeans of all races. This has, I believe, Sir, helped substantially to build the peaceful harmonious Singapore that we have today.

    The second reason for studying English is more pragmatic. It is to equip our children with the necessary means to make their way in the modern technological society that Singapore is today. Without an adequate knowledge of an international language like English, as all countries in the world are finding today, our students will be handicapped in furthering their education and preparing themselves for gainful employment.

    The problem, Sir, for the Ministry of Education is, therefore, not only the study of the mother tongue, which is necessary to enable our children to retain their cultural identity and to strengthen traditional values, but also to ensure that all our children acquire an adequate standard in English so that they will be able to get a good start in life. This is the real problem.

    Considerable progress has been made in the teaching of English in the last 10 years. We have recruited many English teachers and introduced innovations like REAP and other teaching techniques. Standards of English in our schools have consequently risen. For example, the pass rate in English at 'O' level, which used to be the stumbling block for students wanting to go on to higher education, increased from 40% in 1980 to 67% last year. Indeed, Sir, the percentage of our children passing English at 'O' level is today comparable to that of English children in England. This is an achievement in which we can take considerable pride. What it means is that our education system today provides the means for our children, all of them, to have a good start in life.

    Now, Sir, with regard to the study of the mother tongue, the basic approach of the

Column: 337

Ministry of Education is to have two tracks. The first track is for children who are academically able and who would like to study their mother tongue at first language level, and the second track is for the majority of children who will learn their mother tongue at second language level.

    For those who would like to study Chinese at first language level (CL1), we now have the 10 primary SAP schools, 9 secondary SAP schools and from this year, two junior colleges offering CL1 in the Language Elective programme. This provides the opportunity for roughly 10% of our school population who are academically able and who would like to study Chinese at first language level in addition to English.

    For Malay or Indian children, who would like to study Malay or Tamil at first language level, we have established language centres where children can study ML1 or TL1 at the secondary school level. And, as I have stated many times, if there is demand for Malay or Indian children to study ML1 or TL1 at the primary or at the junior college level, we will institute arrangements to make this possible.

    In a multi-racial society like Singapore, the Government must take an even-handed attitude to all our three official languages - Malay, Chinese and Tamil. If there is demand, we will make it possible for Malay and Indian children to study ML1 and TL1, just as we have made arrangements for Chinese children to study CL1 in addition to English.

    Now, Sir, the main problem when people talk about bilingualism in Singapore is the study of Chinese as a second language, CL2, the subject brought up by Dr Hong Hai in yesterday's debate. This is a matter of continuing concern to my Ministry. We know that the majority of our children do not have problems with the study of CL2. They can tackle it in addition to their other subjects and they are able to pass CL2 without undue stress or difficulty. Last year, for example, the percentage of children who pass CL2 at the 'O' and 'AO' levels were 92% and 85% respectively. The majority of our children therefore experience no great difficulty in learning CL2 in addition to learning English.

Column: 338

However, Sir, we know that some children have difficulties with the learning of CL2.

    There are essentially two groups of children who may have difficulties with the study of CL2. The first group comprises children who are not academically able and who naturally find difficulty with CL2 as with the other subjects. These children simply need more time and a slower pace of work so that they will be able to cover the material without being unduly rushed. With the arrangements which we have now made in our schools, this is possible on a systematic basis.

    The second group of children who have difficulties with CL2 are those who are academically bright and who do well in their other subjects but who do poorly in CL2. For these children, the problem is perhaps more of attitude rather than aptitude. It is important, Sir, that children who have difficulties with CL2 should not be dismissed. We should take a sympathetic attitude towards them and see how their difficulties can be overcome. My Ministry is therefore constantly trying to find ways to make the study of CL2 more interesting and to reduce the stress.

    Our basic approach is to follow the principle, which I have stated in Parliament on a previous occasion, that children learn best when they want to learn. Towards this end, we have introduced improved methods for the teaching of CL2 which are more pupil-oriented. There is a certain amount of repetition and memorisation which has to be done in learning a language like Chinese which uses characters instead of an alphabet. This is unavoidable. The work simply has to be done but to the extent that we can, we should help children to learn the characters by means of better textbooks, better teaching methods, more audio-visual aids, more interesting lessons and, if necessary, more time given to supplementary lessons outside normal school hours.

    To make Chinese more interesting, the Ministry is producing supplementary readers in order to help children to read Chinese at the primary school level. By next year, we will have produced 240 such supplementary readers. These readers will use the same set of characters which are

Column: 339

required for the PSLE. They will expose the children to a greater variety of reading materials and enable them to acquire familiarity with the characters.

    In addition, the Ministry is also working with a number of primary and secondary schools, which have a significant number of children who are bright but who appear to have problems coping with Chinese. The Ministry is working with the principals and teachers of these schools to see how their pupils can be helped to learn Chinese with greater enjoyment and success. With the assistance of Chinese Language specialists from the Ministry, the teachers in these schools are using more interactive teaching approaches and providing more opportunities for pupils to use Chinese in school situations. Where additional teachers are needed by the schools, they have been provided by the Ministry. All this, Sir, together with smaller teaching groups should help the schools to improve their pass rates in Chinese and make the CL2 pass rates more comparable with their high pass rates in the other subjects.

    Sir, I have more to say but I may be reaching the end of my time. Should I sit down before I continue?

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock (Ayer Rajah): Sir, the Minister seems to be concentrating on the weaknesses of CL2 among the students. I think there is a bias towards the English educated. This is a feeling among some of our Singaporeans. What steps has the Ministry taken to help those who are weak in the English language?

     Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Sir, before I deal with the question from the Member, perhaps I can continue with the rest of my speech, with the Member's permission.

    Sir, I just want to point out to Members the uniqueness of our situation. Sir, I do not know of any other country in the world which tries to make an entire population bilingual in two languages. Most countries which teach their children more than one language educate their children in their mother tongue first in their early years of school. The children then pick up the second language in the later part of their

Column: 340

school career. But no system in the world, Sir, tries to educate an entire population so that every one is literate in English and at the same time has a reasonable knowledge of his mother tongue. In Japan and Taiwan, for example, the children are educated essentially in Japanese and in Chinese respectively. The learning of English in these two countries only comes at a much later stage in life.

    The nearest to our situation is Switzerland. But even then, Sir, the Swiss Confederation is split up into French speaking, German speaking and Italian speaking communities. A child in Zurich, for example, which is in the German speaking community, would be educated primarily in German at the primary school level. He only starts to learn some conversational French but without taking any examinations towards the end of primary school. It is only in secondary school that French and English are introduced as formal school subjects.

    Sir, I believe that the problems of implementing a bilingual policy of education in a multi-racial society like Singapore have not been sufficiently addressed. There are many issues which, to my mind, require further investigation. One issue, Sir, for example, which has worried some of our more thoughtful and perceptive principals in our SAP schools, is the long term social consequences of teaching children almost exclusively of one race in a system where they do not have the opportunity to interact daily and frequently with children of other races during a very formative period of their lives. These principals are concerned as to whether their pupils will, in later life, be able to interact easily with children of other races and develop an instinctive understanding and respect for traditions which are different from those of their own. Sir, we need to foster a core of students who are able to use Chinese at first language level. Some of these students will continue to study Chinese at university level and, in due course, help to transmit the language by occupying key positions in our society as teachers, media personnel, diplomats or businessmen.

    It is for this reason that we need the SAP schools and the Language Elective pro-

Column: 341

gramme in junior college. We should note that students in the SAP schools have opportunities to mix with children of other races, for example, when they go to junior college or when they are in national service. But nevertheless, Sir, having regard to the concern of the principals, should we not seek to improve the system by consciously providing more opportunities to enable the students in the SAP schools to interact with children of other schools and other races?

    Now, Sir, another issue. This concerns the intellectual requirement for Chinese children to learn two languages - English and Chinese - which are completely different linguistically. English has a phonetic alphabet while Chinese uses ideographs to construct words. When a child learns two European languages, English and French or French and German, we know that the key is to teach the children on an oral basis first, ie, to learn to use the language orally, to listen, to speak and to understand before going into the grammar and the spelling. Once the child is comfortable with the spoken language, the writing and reading then come more naturally.

    The question which we have to ask ourselves is: Does this also apply to Chinese which uses ideographs and not a phonetic alphabet? How much does oral fluency in Chinese help children to read and to write Chinese characters? If it is established that attaining oral proficiency in Chinese does help children significantly to get a better grasp of the language, should we therefore not restructure our teaching and our examinations to put emphasis on speaking, listening and understanding the language rather than on memorising and reproducing characters on demand? This would provide the opportunity for a more interactive, more interesting type of teaching and learning and make the study of the language more enjoyable, as Dr Hong Hai has suggested, and possibly lessen the anxiety of parents and students. But we cannot make such decisions off the cuff. The issues have to be studied carefully.

    A third issue, Sir - how many Chinese characters should a child know so that he

Column: 342

can be considered to have acquired a reasonable knowledge of the language and how should the study of these characters be distributed between primary and secondary schools? Sir, Members may remember a few months ago it was reported in the press that Japanese and Korean students need to learn only 2,000 Chinese characters and 1,000 Chinese characters respectively by the time they reach 12th grade, ie, when they are 18 years old and they are still able to read their own newspapers. Of course, Japanese and Korean are not the same as Chinese. As Members will probably know, modern Japanese is written in a mixture of three components - Kanji, Hiragana and Katakana. Kanji are Chinese characters while Hiragana and Katakana are sets of syllables which make up two separate syllabic alphabets. Kanji is used mainly for content words, such as nouns, verbs and adjectives while Hiragana and Katakana are used for specific Japanese words, to perform grammatical functions, to denote pronouns, adverbs and conjunctions and to render foreign words into Japanese.

    The Korean writing system consists of Hanja which is mainly based on Chinese characters and Hangul which is the original Korean script. Korea has, of course, gone much further than Japan in using a phonetic script to denote both Hangul and Hanja characters.

    The experience of our children learning Chinese is therefore not strictly comparable to that of Japanese children learning Japanese or Korean children learning Korean. But nevertheless, Sir, as Japanese and Korean children learn Japanese and Korean as their mother tongue and their first language and having regard to another press report in the Chinese press which quoted a Professor from the Beijing Institute of Languages, as saying that, with a knowledge of 3,000 characters, one would be able to read newspapers in Chinese, are we not overloading our students who study Chinese as a second language by requiring them to learn 3,000 characters by the time they reach 'O' level? Should we not update our words list which was last compiled in 1982, and see if we can make do with fewer characters and still give our children a reasonable proficiency in Chinese?

Column: 343



    With regard to spreading the study of characters between primary and secondary school, we know that Chinese is not an easy language to learn and it could be advantageous for children to learn as much Chinese as possible in primary schools in order to build a firm foundation for the study of the language before the children proceed to secondary schools where they will have to study many more academic subjects. The question then arises as to how much time can we devote to Chinese at the primary school level without permanently handicapping the pupil in his learning of English and the other academic subjects. Unfortunately, our experience in this matter has not been very encouraging. Our previous attempt to give an early start and hence, more time to the learning of Chinese to about 10% of our primary school pupils in the pre-primary classes was not successful and, as Members will know, this has to be discontinued.

    We are now making a fresh start with the Preparatory Year programme for five years old in the 10 primary SAP schools. Here, our aim is to try and lay a sound foundation in Chinese by taking advantage of the Chinese primary school ethos in these schools and utilizing redesigned curricula and teaching materials. If this can be done successfully, and the signs are hopeful, we then have to consider whether or not we should extend the system to more schools and thereby effectively have our children start school earlier at five years instead of six years. This is a major issue which should be carefully studied before any decision is taken.

    Sir, my point in mentioning all of this is to point out that the Ministry of Education, as an operational Ministry, is not the best institution to look into these issues, many of which require intensive long term research. The Ministry has to deal with day-to-day problems. I believe that we need a centre or an institute in Singapore which can study issues not of the teaching of languages as such but of the implementation of the bilingual policy in our multi-racial society. In my view, Sir, the most appropriate institution to set up

Column: 344

such a centre or institute for the study of bilingualism in our society would be one of our tertiary institutions, possibly the proposed National Institute of Education.

    I have therefore asked the working committee, which is looking into the establishment of the NIE, to consider the possibility of the NIE, perhaps in association with other relevant and interested bodies, sponsoring an institute or a centre to look into all the problems and issues connected with the implementation of the bilingual policy in Singapore. If this centre or institute can be set up, it could be of considerable assistance to us in resolving many of the problems and issues which we face today.

    Sir, I have explained at some length the steps which the Ministry of Education is taking in order to make the study of the mother tongue by our students less stressful and more enjoyable. Our objective must be that by the time a student finishes his general education at the age of 16 at 'O' level, he will have, in addition to a high standard of English, reasonable fluency in his mother tongue and a sound foundation on which, should he wish, he can build on to enhance his proficiency in the language. It will take us some years to realise this objective but it is something which is worthwhile for us to work towards.

    Sir, I apologize to the Member for taking so much of his time before coming round to his question. But as I said, Sir, we are paying as much attention to the teaching of English as to the teaching of Chinese. I am happy to inform him now that with the new materials and new techniques which we have in our primary and secondary schools, plus giving more time to those pupils who need help, the majority of our children are now able to reach an adequate standard in English. As I pointed out, Sir, the percentage of our students who now pass English at '0' level is comparable to those of English children taking the same examination in England. And for those children who need more time, ie, those children who come from dialect-speaking homes or non English-speaking homes, for example, this is a matter of concern to us. We will continue looking into it.

Column: 345



    One advantage which we have, Sir, with regard to the teaching of English in Singapore is that we are not the only country doing so. There are an innumerable number of centres and experts in England, America, Australia, Canada, all looking into this matter. Therefore, there is a huge variety of teaching materials and techniques which are constantly in use. My Ministry has been able to take advantage of these new materials. We constantly look out for new techniques to make the teaching and learning of English much more interesting and we will continue to do so.

    Much obliged, Sir.

     The Senior Minister of State for Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon): Sir, I just want to reply to two speakers yesterday.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock: Sir, can I request the Ministers not to give us such long answers. I think we Backbenchers have no time. They are eating into our time. Thank you.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, I completely agree with the Member and I am just going to answer the points made by Dr Arthur Beng and Dr Ong Chit Chung yesterday. They raised the question of single-session schools and I thought I should just answer them before we move on to the next subhead.

    Sir, the Government has agreed to implement in phases single-session schools for secondary schools. The position to-date is that 47 out of the 140 secondary schools are already functioning as single-session schools. 37 more existing schools are going to be upgraded over the next two or three years to become single-session schools and 16 new schools are under construction for the single-session programme.

     Dr Tan Cheng Bock: Sir, before I withdraw, can I request Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries to keep their replies short and sweet so that their speeches will not eat into the speaking time of my colleagues and also spare you, Sir, the agony of having to listen to long preamble speeches. With that note, I beg to withdraw.

     Mr Chin Harn Tong (Aljunied GRC)( In Mandarin): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head L be reduced by $10 in respect of Code LA 1500 of the Main Estimates.

    Some of our education policies are constantly changing and they are changing very fast. This has resulted in many parents finding it hard to follow. Although I agree that things cannot remain unchanged because if there is no change it means there is no renewal and no improvement. But when something is constantly changing, parents will find it hard to adjust. This is why we should look at this problem. Let me cite three examples to illustrate these parents' complaints.

    First, take the pre-university admission standard, for example. This has been changed three times to-date. The first admission guideline was a composite standard requiring a pass in five subjects, that is to say, students must take up subjects in arts, science or commerce. These five subjects must be related to their course and the aggregate must not exceed 20 points for admission into junior college.

    The second admission standard is one first language and four other subjects with an aggregate of not more than 17 points in five subjects for admission into junior college.

    The third revision came two years ago, that is, one first language and three main subjects plus any two electives, and this makes a total of six subjects. And the aggregate for six subjects must not exceed 20 points for admission into junior college. The three main subjects must come from arts, science and mathematics.

    Pre-university admission standards have been repeatedly changed. Many parents not only find difficulty in adjusting to the system, but teachers and students also feel they are caught unaware even though the Ministry of Education has given ample time for students to get used to the changes.

    The second example was in 1979 when the Ministry of Education started pre-primary education in 30 primary schools for

Column: 347

the five-year old children. The objective was to provide the extra year for a better foundation to be laid in the two languages. The scheme was warmly received by parents and the role has been increasing all the time and many schools, in order to meet this extra demand, have made adjustments and improvements to accommodate this pre-primary programme. In 1989, the scheme was brought to an end, the reason being that the expenditure did not balance with the result. This change by the Ministry of Education has led to many parents being disappointed and school principals and teachers expressing regrets.

    The third example. In 1984, the Ministry of Education started implementing the Religious Knowledge programme, making it compulsory for Secondary 3 students to take up one Religious Knowledge study. Religious Knowledge consists of six areas in all. Among them, Confucianism, Moral Education and Buddhism can be taught either in English or Chinese, while Islamic Studies can either be taught in English or Malay. The subject is to replace the original civics and current affairs studies. This can also be considered as one of the subjects for admission into pre-university and junior college.

    In 1989, the Ministry announced that the study of Religious Knowledge has become an elective subject, and it is to be taught outside normal school hours. At the same time, it was stated that Religious Knowledge would no longer be considered as one of the entry requirements for university.

    At the moment, the Ministry is now re-writing the Civics syllabus to replace Religious Knowledge which has been implemented for a few years. In order to get RK off the ground, the Ministry has employed experts and consultants from overseas and held many seminars. At the same time, they also ran classes to train teachers how to teach the subject. And more important, a considerable number of teachers have been seconded to the Ministry of Education to work on the syllabus. The amount of money and time the Ministry has spent on the programme has been

Column: 348

considerable. Although at the moment, the subject is still in existence, it has lost its effectiveness.

    Sir, from the above three examples, we can see that certain major policies of the Ministry of Education are constantly changing and it is little wonder that parents and teachers all feel the same, that is, no policy will stay very long. Of course, policy changes are something that are unavoidable because new situations are constantly arising and we have to make the necessary adjustments to accommodate the demands. But when these changes are too fast and too often, it will lead to many people feeling lost, and at the same time, they feel that the planners lack foresight. This is particularly true with education because education is a long-term pursuit. Just as the saying goes, it takes 10 years for a tree to grow, but 100 years for the spirit to be established.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Sir, I am on an entirely different topic. I would like to address the use of school premises in the evenings.

    Sir, school facilities such as basketball courts and halls are scarce resources, especially for schools located within HDB estates, which I will call neighbourhood schools. Column: 349

at substantial cost. By speaking up here, I do not mean to scale back the scope of community centres. They are fulfilling a very different and useful mission.      Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights): Sir, the bilingual policy has been the hallmark and cornerstone of our education system. Apart from those who are studying in the SAP schools, most students are taking English as first language and learning mother language at second language level.

Column: 350

the compulsory study of mother tongue, especially Chinese. In particular, they feel strongly against the requirement of compulsory passing of the second language for promotions and entering university. They possess two keys, one to the east and one to the west. So doing away with the second language requirement is also not the right answer to their specific problems. I believe those Singaporeans who have difficulty with Chinese come mainly from the English-speaking homes. Like most of us in this House, they are part of the colonial past. They are monolingual. As parents, the main problem is their inability to provide a conducive home environment for their

children to learn Chinese. So to solve the problem, they must hit the nail on the head.

but the appeal was turned down. I hope the Minister can reconsider this case.

     Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, it used to be that in all our primary schools, each class had a form teacher. This form teacher taught the core subjects of English, Mathematics, Science and Social Studies and remained in that class for the greater part of each day. He or she was the father or mother figure to the pupils of that class. The form teacher and his or her pupils were able to build between them the kind of relationship and rapport, the lasting bond which is an essential element in a desirable teacher-pupil relationship. The form teacher knew each of his or her pupils well and the pupils in turn knew their teacher. This helped to improve discipline and enhance the opportunities to inculcate sound moral values.

    Today, in all our primary schools there is the emerging phenomenon of the multi-teacher or "international class" as it is commonly called. The class has no form teacher in the sense that I have described. The chores of marking the attendance and collecting the fees are undertaken by a second language teacher who spends very little time there. And for the rest of the day, several different teachers come in and out of the class to teach the various subjects. Hence the label "international class". It is a well-known fact in our schools that the international class usually lacks discipline and is difficult to manage. These children do not benefit from the permanent stabilising effect of having a form teacher as a father or mother figure.

    We have international classes in our primary schools because the staffing quota or the permitted teacher complement, as it is called, is inadequate. The permitted teacher complement formula is such that it does not allow for one EL1 teacher per class in schools where English is taught as the first language or one CL1 teacher per class where Chinese is taught as the first language. If we believe that primary education is important, we must provide our schools with adequate manpower so that they can be run well. A more liberal staffing quota, in addition to the present complement of second language and other teachers, which will enable

Column: 353

every class to have a form teacher to look after the pupils for the greater part of each day is extremely desirable.

    In our secondary schools, the staffing quota is a little more generous but with the teachers specialising in certain subjects and unable to teach all subjects, there are also problems. Giving a couple more teachers to schools involved in special projects like pastoral care and off-loading technical and domestic science teachers does not help, again because these teachers are limited by their specialisation. The workload of those who teach the core subjects of English, Mathematics and Science and subjects like Literature, History and Geography is still a very heavy one. Just as in the primary schools, there is a good case for the more liberal staffing quota in secondary schools. All efforts to improve our education system will be seriously hampered if in our schools we do not have adequate manpower to do the job better. Will the Ministry of Education not consider increasing the staffing quota for schools with suitable teachers?

    (2) the total student enrolment of that Department at NUS;

    (3) its staff strength; and

Column: 354

the information I wanted as absolutely secret. But I cannot see why it should be kept away from a Member of Parliament if he wanted to have those information.

    The Government has a massive programme to encourage Chinese Singaporeans to speak Mandarin and we have heard speakers in this House talking of the concern for the promotion of the second language. We have just heard a talk about the bilingual policy and its problems. If the Government is really serious about promoting Mandarin amongst the Chinese population, then I think, first of all, it should tackle the problem of whether there are enough teachers to teach our students in this particular language.

The Prime Minister said the problem is big. Maybe we will solve it by recruiting from Hong Kong and Taiwan to supplement the few that we can find. This may well be good for the newspapers and for the TV station, but certainly not for our schools. We do not want to have foreigners in massive numbers coming to interact with our local Singaporeans. They may pass on the wrong values to our Singaporeans and, in that process, we will have problems building up a Singapore identity.

    There is in fact urgent need to look into the enlargement of the Chinese Studies

Column: 355

Department if the Government is really serious about wanting to keep Mandarin alive in Singapore. If the number of school children becomes so great, there might even be a necessity to revive or set up a Chinese university, just to produce the number of graduates to keep up with the massive demands for the people who are versed in Mandarin. Sir, I think the Government should really address itself on this problem. They must go for the jugular and not just superficial statements and campaigns made to promote the language. But in fact there is no real substance in those campaigns.

    Sir, my second cut is in regard to the expansion of vocational education in Singapore. I welcome the setting up of the third polytechnic. It is a good move. But I am more concerned with the younger children who have left school prematurely, those drop-outs in Primary 6, Secondary 1 or Secondary 2. Where do they go? Where do they get their training? Perhaps the Minister could give his thought to those who have left school earlier. What sort of vocational training, what sort of skill, what sort of vocation can they be trained in? But, of course, there is still more room even to train our school leavers because if we are to be an industrialized country, vocational training is very important. The Minister has said that he has looked at the German and Swiss experience and he would know that in Germany, 65% of the children between the ages of 15-18 years have some kind of vocational training. It is no wonder their nation is industrially so advanced. Perhaps we should try and emulate that kind of standard.

    As regards the status of our students who are trained in the polytechnic, I hear that they are not given the status which they deserve. I hear that NTC2 graduates are still treated like 'O' level students. I think the Minister should also look into the possibility of in-house training for some of our school leavers. Perhaps they could encourage firms to give more in-house training.

    The other question is the recruitment of foreign workers. Are we to recruit more and more skilled workers to compete with

Column: 356

our skilled workers here? Is that fair? Because we have spent massive amounts of money training our Singaporeans and they may be deprived of jobs to compete with other skilled workers from foreign countries who may be paid less.

    My third amendment refers to reducing the school class size. This is a very important area which I have brought up many times in this House and I have not yet, up till now, got a satisfactory reply. I think it is unreasonable to ask the Minister to implement this very important policy straightaway. Perhaps he could stretch it out over five to 10 years but the aim must be there. From the educational point of view, there is no doubt that there are a lot of benefits of having a small class size so that the teachers could pay more individual attention to the poorer pupils. This principle has been accepted in the independent schools. The independent schools, I would say, will accept pupils of above average intelligence and they get the benefit of educational facilities which other schools are deprived of. Why prejudice against other schools? Why favour only the independent schools? I would like the Minister to commit and to admit that he will look into this area and perhaps try to implement this policy of really reducing the class size. If the class is too big, it is just impossible for the teacher to teach effectively. Perhaps we will see less and less of our school students dropping out from schools prematurely.

     The Chairman: Yes.

     Encik Yatiman Yusof: Sir, the problem arising from an increasing number of our children pursuing their education abroad and the possibility of brain drain arising from it is not new. It has been a subject keenly discussed and debated by many quarters - educationists, education planners, teachers and parents. However, Sir, I feel that we have not found the most effective way of tackling this problem. Since manpower and human resource still remains the only source of our future survival and development, we have to do the best to overcome this problem.

Column: 357



    Since we last talked about education abroad and its negative effect to our human resource, the problem has taken a new dimension. Not only had the cases increased in number but also the type of people, their quality and the possible loss of use of their contribution to Singapore had also increased. With a greater number of students enrolled in the English stream, an increase in the number of those who succeed in their pre-university examinations and the widening area of qualifications, both in the academic and technical fields, the tendency to seek further education abroad is becoming greater.

    The increase in intake of students by NUS, NTI, and the Polytechnics has, to some extent, increased the opportunity, but it has not solved the problem. So is the new plan for the second university and the third polytechnic.

    Sir, the upsurge or quest for higher education among our people is a healthy one. Individually, it is a clear manifestation of our desire to achieve excellence in life. Collectively, it is a "take-off" stage towards creating a knowledge-oriented society, a path which we have long pursued in the hope that the total cumulative result would be to help us to build a solid platform, a spring board, towards a new height for our society, our nation and our civilization.

    In view of this, I welcome the series of new efforts announced by the Minister recently. By widening and broadening the scope of education and training at national level, we will be able to cater for the increasing need for our people in the field of education. However, Sir, there is a limit to what we can do. Many students will still continue to pursue their education abroad. The reasons are multi-faceted - some for personal reasons, some for intellectual reasons and some for practical and pragmatic reasons.

    It is my humble submission that unless we act vigorously to strengthen their roots in Singapore, emotionally and ideologically, creating a strong sense of belonging, a sense of meaningful sharing of the future, we may end up unsuccessful or, worse still, a loser.

Column: 358



    In this respect, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister for his long term plan and strategy to cultivate our pupils so that their feet may temporarily be abroad but their hearts and minds are in Singapore.

    Sir, on the question of coordination between institutions of higher learning and research and development programme, we are fully aware that the importance of close cooperation between the institutions of higher learning and our R&D programme need not be emphasized. It has long been a proven formula for a nation's success in its economy and development.

    By sharing and tapping each other's resources through a well-planned. well-coordinated and well-programmed project, we will be mutually enriching our ability in R&D. In this respect, Sir, I would like to take the opportunity to ask the Minister for an update in the cooperation in this sphere. I would be glad too, Sir, if the Minister could share with the House his thinking on this issue, especially the future direction his Ministry intends to pursue on this matter.

    The adult education programme. Sir, continual education has a long history in Singapore. It is a milestone to our social mobility too. Singaporeans are fortunate because the avenue for the pursuit of knowledge, upgrading of qualifications and skills remains open for them, especially for the working adult population. The Ministry, through its various programmes and schemes, such as the VITB, has helped many who had missed the opportunity in their formal education, to better themselves. In addition, the Skills Development Fund is always available for firms to upgrade the employees' skill and ability.

    Sir, with compulsory primary education and implementation of continual education programme in schools, we have created a better environment and better opportunity for our students. However, Sir, despite all these efforts and schemes, I would like to emphasize the need for us to give special and additional attention to those who realise, alas not belatedly, their mistake and choose to better themselves in the later stage of their life. In this respect, may I ask the Minister whether he intends to broaden the scope for adult

Column: 359

education and what kind of incentive, apart from personal satisfaction, it provides to those who try to better themselves academically.

     Dr Lee Siew-Choh (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, I speak on the Dainton's Report. The Government has accepted Lord Dainton's recommendations to build two universities. But from the reading of the Report, it would appear that Singapore needs, not two, but three universities. The simple reason is that more and more of our students are seeking university education. This is supported by:

    (1) "The growth of students who wish to have university education has been more rapid than foreshadowed in my report about 10 years' ago", says Lord Dainton.

    (2) About 9,000 Singapore students are currently studying overseas in institutions of higher education.

    (3) The Report refers to past postgraduate students and major students.

    (4) With the natural increase in Singapore's population, and I quote again, "the size of the 18-year-old age group would be significantly larger were Singapore's population to rise to 4 million".

    (5) Lord Dainton warns against over reliance on performance in 'A' level examinations. Therefore cautious liberalization of admission criteria will certainly increase the number of students seeking higher education.

    From all this, Sir, it can be seen that early in 1979 the projected number of students seeking higher education was already grossly underestimated in spite of the then prevailing "Stop at two" policy. The present 1989 projected number would certainly again be grossly underestimated, especially when the Government is presently pushing new procreation policies. In fact, it is already obvious that by the end of the 1970s there was already a four to five-fold upsurge in demand for university education. The problem was compounded by Government's decision to merge the Nanyang University with the then Univer-

Column: 360

sity of Singapore to form a single National University of Singapore. Nantah, of course, should not have been scrapped at all. Nantah failed, not simply because its graduates were not as well recognized as the Singapore University graduates, but mainly because the PAP Government had not lived up to its promise to give equal treatment to the four streams of education.

    Following the merging of the two Universities into one, stringent measures were introduced to reduce the number of students seeking university education. This is in keeping with the PAP's policy of elitism. Hence, the Goh Keng Swee's Report with a new system of education and the introduction of streaming. The result of all this, Sir, is that large numbers of students have been denied opportunities to higher education, which in turn has contributed to a large exodus of students all going for higher studies overseas. The lack of facilities for higher education is one of the main reasons for our students going abroad, not because "their hearts are not in Singapore", as Encik Yatiman said.

    The Zaobao has said that in 1980 there were already 3,000 students leaving Singapore for higher education overseas. Today the number, as disclosed in the Report, has increased to 9,000. The Minister says that expansion is in line with the projection of manpower needs. But I say, Sir, that it is a grave mistake to base our national education expansion solely on the manpower needs of foreign MNCs which own most of the industries in Singapore. We should instead, Sir, base our projections on our own national needs to develop our people to their fullest potential. Education should not be seen as merely a means to an end. Education is indeed an end in itself, namely, the fullest development of our citizens as human beings. And in matters of education, we should not be miserly in the use of our surplus funds. We spend too small an amount on education. As the Report has said, and I quote:

    " ... because Singapore is a small island with virtually no natural resources, its economy is more dependent on the skills and intelligence of its people than would be the case for many other countries ..."

And that, Sir, means more funds for the education and training of our people.

Column: 361



    Though we have a small population, we could, like Denmark, still have our own Niels Bohr. We have sufficient manpower and the potential. Just think of the number of students who have been denied their university education because of the now suspended suitability certificates or of the students who have been barred in some way by the streaming of students.

    Our own Chia Thye Poh, Sir, was also a budding physicist. If he had been allowed to have full development of his potential, instead of having been incarcerated in our prisons for more than 23 years, how would we know that we do not also have our own Niels Bohr?

    The whole thrust of my argument, Sir, is that Government should not merely want to upgrade NTI into NTU today. It should not shelve plans for a third university. Instead, it should start preparations for the third university now and not wait and waste time. The Report fears that there may be a lowering of standards if we go too fast. The Report also states that, and I quote:

    "... when the percentage of the 18 year old age group entering higher education rises above the 15-20% band, then the graduation rate diminishes and the attrition rate may, as in the USA, rise to 50%."

This may be over-cautious and over-alarmist. They must not forget that our people's attitude towards education is different from the attitude of US students towards education. Our students study hard and seriously, quite unlike some of the students in the United States. Moreover, necessary and suitable staff can always be recruited to ensure continuing high standards in the university.

    In our quest for excellence and in our march towards the status of a developed nation, let us not forget that the general level of education is one of the most important indicators. Yet, presently, the number of students enrolled in higher education as a percentage of population aged 20 to 40 years in Singapore lags far behind Taiwan, South Korea, Japan and the United States. We should not waste time to catch up. The higher the general level of education, the more will this benefit our country economically, socially, politically and culturally.

Column: 362



    In conclusion, Sir, as I have said, education is not merely a means to an end. Education is an end in itself, which is the development of our people to their fullest potential. Today, our parents and children are demanding that more and more facilities be provided for higher education. Already the Straits Times this morning reports that 16,000 school leavers have applied for 8,700 places in the three polytechnics. We have more than adequate funds. These funds should be put to good use for the benefit of our people.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, I would like to reply to a number of points raised by Members.

    The first is from Mr Chin Harn Tong. In his speech, Mr Chin expressed concern that the Ministry of Education has been making too many policy changes in the last few years. Sir, let me assure him that the Ministry does not wish to make policy changes for the sake of making policy changes. It will be much easier for the Ministry to make no policy changes at all and just carry on with its day-to-day routines. But the Ministry cannot avoid making changes when it sees the need to do so.

    The Ministry regularly reviews all its educational policies and, when necessary, changes are made so that the quality of education can be improved or changes have to be made because needs have changed. However, the long-term mission of the Ministry of Education remains unchanged. It is to bring out the best in every child so that he can grow up to be a responsible citizen and contribute towards the progress of our nation.

    As for the process of making policy changes, the Ministry takes a cautious approach when considering changes in educational policies. It has to bear in mind the interest and welfare of our students - that is the primary concern. Therefore, in

Column: 363

the process, the Ministry seeks the views of school principals, for example, through the Schools Council, teachers as well as members of the public. It also seeks the views of the GPC for Education and on occasions has asked the Feedback Unit to organise public hearings on policy changes that it has in mind.

Column: 364

principal and this arrangement can be done.

    Sir, the Member for Potong Pasir, Mr Chiam See Tong, spoke on a number of topics. I will only answer him on the subject of vocational training and its needs and also the reduction of class sizes. I will leave to my Minister to reply to him on the Chinese Studies Department at NUS.

    Sir, as the Member knows, there is a comprehensive programme available now for school leavers, particularly the premature school leavers, to go on from primary or secondary school into vocational training and to come out as skilled craftsmen and technicians. This programme makes it very easy for premature school leavers to register with the VITB. For example, anybody who leaves primary school on completion of the monolingual course or who is unable to go on to secondary school is automatically registered under the automatic registration scheme in vocational institutes. Column: 365

there. Every year, VITB sends teams of people into all the primary schools to inform them about the courses that are available and the career prospects that follow from these courses.
